## Definitions {.smaller}

 > Measuring and Monitoring Biological Diversity: Standard Methods for Amphibians.  1994.  Eds, Heyer et al.

::: {.incremental}

 - [*Relative abundance*:]{.purple}  proportional representation of species in a sample
 - [*Inventory*:]{.purple}  study of a specific area, site, or habitat to determine the number of species present (i.e. species richness)
 - [*Monitoring*:]{.purple} study of the abundance of individuals in one or more populations of a species at a site through time
 - [*Mark-recapture techniques*:]{.purple}  methods for determining population size that involve capturing, marking, and releasing animals, and subsequently recapturing or re-sighting them one or more times.
 - [*Visual Encounter Survey (VES)*:]{.purple}  estimate the diversity (number of. different species) and abundance (number of different individuals) of animals at a particular location

:::

::: footer
Definitions
:::

# Visual <br>Ecounter<br> Surveys<br> (VES) {.tr .smaller background-image="../img/ALC2023hab.jpg" background-size="contain" background-position="left" background-color="#000000"}


## VES {.smaller}

::: {.columns .pv4}
::: {.column width="65%"}

 - **Search Area**: need GPS of begin/end

:::{.fragment}
 - **Habitat**: 
    - Wetted width / bankfull width
    - Avg depth / max depth
    - turbidity / sedimentation / embeddedness
    - canopy cover
    - geomorphic type (run / riffle / pool)
    - invasives | disturbance
:::

:::{.fragment}
 - **Conditions**: survey conditions important
    - sunny/windy/warm/cold
    - flow/water quality at site
    - air/water temp at site
:::
:::

::: {.column width="35%"}

:::{.fragment}

 - **Search Duration**: crucial to quantify effort
    - Obs times provides information on time-to-detection

![](../img/watch.jpg)

:::
:::
:::

 - Snorkeling highly recommended/mandatory for spring egg mass surveys
 - Suitable for monitoring the abundance & distribution
 - tandem teams ideal for paired survey

##  {.smaller background-image="../img/sk_tracking_egg_fate_curve.png" background-size="contain" background-position="center" background-color="#000000"}

::: footer
from S. Kupferberg, SF Eel
:::

::: notes
cumulative frequency curves from the SF Eel to show that a well timed survey 3-4 weeks after egg laying starts could capture about 90% of the egg laying. In other words at a site with cool temperatures most clutches would not have completely hatched and dispersed, and could still be counted.
:::

## PIT Tagging {.smaller}

 - [*PIT tag*:]{.purple} a marking tag made of a passive integrated transponder (PIT) that relies on passive radio-frequency identification of a 10-digit hexadecimal number, read with a scanner and portable reader.  
 
![](../img/pit_tags.png){fig-align="center"}

## e-DNA (Environmental DNA) {.smaller}

![Machler et al. 2014. Freshwater Science](../img/edna_overview.png)

::: {.fragment .tc}
 - Filter a lot of water
 - Clean/sterile replicates
 - Cover more ground (but not proof of absence)
:::
